Many answers to the question of why college costs so much of course, but part of it is spending on other-than-academics. Typical residential student these days enjoys quite good food, private (vs. 2 person) dorm rooms, attractive campus with great fitness centers and other facilities, plus an army of non-teaching support staff, some providing student services (e.g., counselors) and some just dealing with bureaucratic red tape.

Colleges compete to attract 18 year old students taking campus tours, and it is easier to display these aesthetics than it is to show high-quality instruction. So it is logical that colleges invest in perqs and facilities.

It'd be nice to figure out how to get colleges to back off this arms race of amenities and pass the savings along in lower tuition & lower loan burden, but not sure how to get there.
Those college VPs make car dealers seem like Mother Teresa. Desperate to protect their wallets.

This isn't really addressing the main issue. Why is the student taking out $50,000 in loans, instead of whatever the inflation adjusted tuition amount from 1970 is? Certainly the author knows most professors aren't paid very much. Many professors might only make $50,000.

Where is the money going? Why couldn't the student complete college and only be $25,000 in debt? Certainly it's an uncontroversial proposition that a college graduate would be happier to only have $25,000 in loans rather than $50,000.

As an erudite writer put it, * * *
Those who regret the end of Qaddafi’s regime ignore how the current chaos is the product of four decades of oppression. “Wasn’t Qaddafi better?” is the wrong question, because it doesn’t illuminate the objective reality of post-revolutionary Libya. To understand today’s events, one must remember what life was like under Qaddafi. The state was designed around an individual and his family; it resembled more a Mafia than a political structure. And so ending the dictatorship meant ending the state.

Without a fully functioning national army and police force, and other state institutions, building an accountable and democratic government is going to be immensely hard.

Modern Libya is sixty-five years old, dating from 1951. For almost two-thirds of that time, it was ruled by one voice. In light of this history, creating a political atmosphere that permits and encourages difference and plurality has, indeed, been difficult.

Lessons

Josh Hill -- We have seen repeatedly for half a century that military aid comes with Americans to deliver it, see that it goes to the right people and stays there, maintain it, train a steady stream of locals in its use, and advise it its proper use. Next it is necessary to protect all of those Americans. That is how Vietnam started, on exactly those terms. Military aid always since has followed the pattern of Americans with American weapons. That is not bad faith, that is necessary. Our weapons are like that.

"Nation building" is a discredited idea, and justly so.

Military aid and national building are not alternatives to intervention. They are intervention. They inevitably come with protection when things go wrong. Notice a big reason for the current bombing is to protect the Americans in the Kurdish capital.

You are urging a distinction that is not real. It is make believe, like nation building itself as an idea.

It is simply not known if this drug, ZMapp, has any efficacy. The 2 patients treated thus far may or may not have benefitted from it. One essential ethical requirement is that those who are given the drug provide full, informed consent to its use. It may help and it may not; it may cause harm. It is also necessary, in the setting of a limited resource, to offer ZMapp to those most likely to benefit, and this seems, from the little described in press stories about animal studies, is people who show early signs of the disease. Optimally, for purposes of evaluating its worth, ZMapp can be used in those who have been tested and confirmed to have an ebola infection. With these patients, an invaluable case series will quickly be available to suggest that ZMapp is efficacious, harmful, or useless.

It is without question that many facing this disease, with at least a 50% case fatality rate, would agree to roll the dice and try ZMapp.

The only way this is an issue is because the media is playing it up. But the media has reporters and photographers in the infected countries covering this story. They are putting their lives at risk and show how the media can be responsible and heroic.

Why don't we make all the drug companies seeking cures give away their secrets so that other companies might run with them and find a cure faster? I'm sure they wouldn't mind handing over years of their hard work and financial investment if it meant that people might get saved. The answer is that they are getting paid to find a cure and that if there were not this great incentive then there would be no research into many of these drugs.

If you mean for pharma companies to do it, you'll have to make it worth their while, Sandy.  That is why the companies work on acid reflux and erectile dysfunction drugs--the repeat doses, the steady money.  If we mean to deal with public health emergencies that take one dose, and to satisfy the for-profit demands of the "market", we'd better consider--gasp!--being willing to pay taxes for them.  And in the US, that has become the unforgiveable sin in many quarters, it appears.  This is just likely to be one of the many costs of deciding not to pool our money through taxation; as public goods continue to break down, there will be more.

Perhaps some sort of licensing arrangement could be worked out that removes liability from the possible ill effects of these untested drugs as well as some monetary compensation for the inventors.
But maybe this is already in the works.

Ridem applies a wrong model by multiplying a small probability of infection by the number of people in the usa. This would be right only if all people were exposed, but only very few people are actually exposed. His dire predictions are therefore wrong : even if new infections were to occur the spread can be easily contained by isolation measures that are quite effective, as we see from the small numbers of medical staff that actually get infected.

I acknowledge your point.Think of an exposure rate of <1.0%, with an acute infection rate (requiring hospitalization for half of that number. Toss in a random number of suspected but ultimately unproven cases into the mix. With the "fear factor" , you can see that the number of clinic and ER visits will be exponentially greater than the actual "infected rate" or even the risk of having been infested.
If you want to move away from the "dire" scenario- use 35,000 infected folks requiring hospitalization in the limited scenario of outbreaks in the Atlanta MSA,Baltimore-DC area, and Houston and Los Angeles MSA.What's that? 7K sick/ infected /requiring hospitalization plus another 50K suspected,(pending lab results) per city. Pity the folks at the testing labs too--they will be overwhelmed and fearful. Absenteeism 30-40%
I have spent 35+ years in direct patient care in major med centers. It's laughable to think of the number of times I've been notified a week after the fact by infection control that my patient had active drug resistant TB, MRSA, scabies , influenza, and other communicable diseases. With "universal precautions I should be at minimal risk-IF THE OTHER GUY IS CARRYING HER/HIS WEIGHT. Twice in my career I've had fluid/blood exposures and needle sticks due to MD failure to observe strict protocols.The number of co-workers personally known to me with HIV and HepC needle sticks is around 60-70.
I'm not alarmist,or pessimistic. An experienced realist? Yes.

Even if 5 million doses were produced in the US and available by Dec 25, I know that it would be reserved for "first-responders, critical medical staff,and the military. I'm also pretty sure that the 1% and their political lackeys will manage to jump the queue as well.

What troubles me most, ignored in all of these discussions is IF only 0.005 of the US population becomes infected infected- you are talking about 1.5 million people, which will utterly overwhelm the US health care system.

Coupled with the "fear factor" it's unlikely that the transportation system-delivery of fuel,food,and medical supplies (which includes water) would remain functioning after even a "modest outbreak" limited to the East Coast and a few big cities in the western states. Say affecting only 0.001 of the population (about 350,000 people).

I think the ethics an logistics of who gets the limited number of doses,is overwhelmed, by the economic destruction wrought by fear alone.

"As it is we only have 21st century weapons to combat the most extreme and most desperate acting out battles in the name of some warped vision of Islam."

Whether biopharma will help in useful quantities during this outbreak is really not the point. They were never incentivized to start down that path. Where's the ROI?
It is rather that these countries where Ebola is spreading are the "perfect storm" of multiple factors contributing to widespread infection, inadvertent daily habits and means of coping with the sick, the dying, and preparing the dead for burial.

As it is we only have 21st century weapons to combat the most extreme and most desperate acting out battles in the name of some warped vision of Islam.

I suspect that these people were given the drug because they were available, because they could give informed consent, and because they might be more willing to make themselves available as long term guinea pigs. Another is that they will be immune (if they live) and are likely to return to Africa to work with people affected by the epidemic. There is no doubt that these people are courageous , they were treating people with Ebola in Africa.  The problem is that there is no "drug", in the small molecule, make it in the lab or factory sense. There is also no vaccine. Only quarantine can stop this disease.
The people cannot be kept alive simply by giving them "state of the art" medical care. This disease kills and it is a toss-up as to whether one will live or die. Seventeen out of twenty will die.
